case_name: President, Vice-President and Secretary of the Hindu Mahasabha of the Delhi State v. Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate, Delhi

facts.text: Three petitions presented to Supreme Court under article 32 for habeas corpus for release of petitioners

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, J. These three petitions have been presented to this Court under article 32 of the Constitution of India praying for the issue of writs in the nature of habeas companypus for release of the petitioners

facts.text: Mahajan J dissented holding detention illegal due to insufficient grounds

issues.text: Whether the provisions of the Preventive Detention Act can be used to detain persons for making speeches prejudicial to the maintenance of public order given that Article 19(2) does not authorise restrictions on freedom of speech for public order

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the petitioners Mr. Hardy submitted that the provisions of the Act should not be used to prevent a citizen from making speeches though they might be considered to be prejudicial to the maintenance of public order, for maintenance of public order is not a purpose for which imposition of a restriction on freedom of speech is authorised by the Constitution, as held by this Court in the Cross-Roads 1950 S.C.R. 594 and the Organizer 1950 S.C.R. 605 cases.

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention are too vague and indefinite to enable the petitioners to make effective representations under Article 22(5)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Hardy next contended that, in view of the recent decision of this Court in The State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya 1951 S.C.R. 167, the grounds of detention communicated to each of the petitioners must be held to be too vague and indefinite to enable them to make their representations to the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, and the requirements of clause  5  of article 22 not having thus been complied with, the petitioners were entitled to be set at liberty.

issues.text: Whether the orders of detention were bad because they did not specify the period during which the petitioners were to be under detention

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that the orders of detention were bad because they did not specify the period during which the petitioners were to be under detention. This point is not concluded against the petitioners by the decision of this Court in Ujager Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 149 of 1950

issues.text: Whether the orders of detention were made for the collateral purpose of stifling political opposition indicating mala fides

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was said that the petitioners were prominent members of a political organisation which was opposed to the ideals and policies of the party in power, and that the orders of detention were made for the collateral purpose of stifling effective political opposition and legitimate criticism of the policies pursued by the Congress Party

issues.text: Whether what is stated in the grounds is sufficient material on the basis of which the fundamental right conferred by Article 22(5) can be adequately exercised without knowing the substance of the offending passages

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision is whether what is stated in the grounds is sufficient material on the basis of which the fundamental right conferred on the petitioners by article 22 5  of the Constitution can be adequately exercised and whether without knowing the substance of the offending passages in the speeches

holdings.text: Preventive detention under section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act is valid even when based on speeches prejudicial to the maintenance of public order, as it is not restricted by Article 19(1)(a) and (2), but tested under Articles 21 and 22.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in those cases this Court decided by a majority of 5 to 1 that unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it such law cannot fall within the reservation of clause  2  of article 19 although the restrictions which it seeks impose may have been companyceived generally in the interests if public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Gopalan case distinguishing personal liberty under Articles 21/22 from freedoms under Article 19; detention directly affects liberty, not speech restrictions.

holdings.text: The grounds of detention are not vague or indefinite; specifying time, place, and general effect of speeches (exciting disaffection between Hindus and Muslims) is sufficient to enable effective representation under Article 22(5), without needing gist or offending passages.

anchor.surface_text: This decision does number, in our opinion, support the board proposition companytended for by Mr. Hardy that wherever an order of detention is based upon speeches made by the person sought to be detained, the detaining authority should companymunicate to the person the offending passages or at least the gist of such passages on pain of having the order quashed if it did number.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Atma Ram Vaidya; not prosecution under IPC ss.124A/153A nor Advisory Board reference; general effect sufficient for representation to executive; omission regrettable but not fatal.

holdings.text: Detention orders are not invalid for failing to specify the period of detention, as section 12 of the Act prescribes a maximum of one year.

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that the orders of detention were bad because they did number specify the period during which the petitioners were to be under detention. This point is number companycluded against the petitioners by the decision of this Court in Ujager Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 149 of 1950 and Jagjit Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 167 of 1950 where it was pointed out that as section 12 of the Act itself prescribed a maximum period of one year for detention thereunder,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Ujager Singh and Jagjit Singh precedents; Act itself limits duration.

holdings.text: No mala fides established in the detention orders; petitioners failed to discharge burden of proof despite District Magistrate's denial.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was said that the petitioners were prominent members of a political organisation which was opposed to the ideals and policies of the party in power, and that the orders of detention were made for the companylateral purpose of stifling effective political opposition and legitimate criticism of the policies pursued by the Congress Party and had numberhing to do with the maintenance of public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allegations denied by affidavit; burden on petitioners not discharged.

holdings.text: The detention orders are legal and petitions are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings upholding detention.

holdings.text: Grounds of detention insufficient without substance or gist of speeches, violating Article 22(5); detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above I venture to dissent from the opinion of the majority of the Court with great respect and hold that the detention orders above mentioned are illegal. I accordingly order the release of the petitioners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Atma Ram Vaidya strictly; speeches public, no privilege; needs particulars like in IPC charges to enable representation.

holdings.text: Executive must provide gist of speeches in grounds for effective representation under Article 22(5); present grounds inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: Bose, J. I agree with my brother Mahajan whose judgment I have had the advantage of reading, and with the utmost respect find myself unable to accept the majority view. I am of opinion that these petitioners should all be released

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words are key in speeches; detenu cannot meet conclusions without premises; liberal construction of rights.
